          32
          Vinyl Sulfonate Esters and Vinyl Sulfonamides: Potent, Irreversible Inhibitors of Cysteine Proteases
          Roush, William R.; Gwaltney, Stephen L., II; Cheng, Jianming; Scheidt, Karl A.; McKerrow, James H.; Hansell, Elizabeth
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (1998), 120 (42), 10994-10995CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          A series of vinyl sulfonate esters, vinyl sulfonamides, and vinyl sulfones I (R = OEt, OPh, NHMe, NHCH2Ph, NHCH2CH2Ph, NHPh, Ph, CH2Ph, CH2CH2Ph; R1 = CH2CH2Ph, Me) was prepd. as an effort to develop potent and selective cruzain inhibitors. Alkyl vinyl sulfonamides, e.g. I (R = NHCH2Ph, R1 = Me), were relatively weak inhibitors of cruzain, while aryl vinyl sulfonamides and sulfonate esters, e.g. I (R = OEt, OPh, NHPh; R1 = Me, CH2CH2Ph) were much more potent.
          >> More from SciFinder ®

        33. 33
          (a) Yoshino, H.; Ueda, N.; Niijima, J.; Sugumi, H.; Kotake, Y.; Koyanagi, N.; Yoshimatsu, K.; Asada, M.; Watanabe, T.; Nagasu, T.; Tsukahara, K.; Iijima, A.; Kitoh, K.           [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          33a
          Novel sulfonamides as potential, systemically active antitumor agents
          Yoshino, Hiroshi; Ueda, Norihiro; Niijima, Jun; Sugumi, Hiroyuki; Kotake, Yoshihiko; Koyanagi, Nozomu; Yoshimatsu, Kentaro; Asada, Makoto; Watanabe, Tatsuo; et al.
          Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (1992), 35 (13), 2496-7CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623.
          A series of N-(2-anilino-3-pyridyl)benzenesulfonamides (I; R=Me or MeO, X=CH or N, Y=CH, COMe, COH, or N) showed potent antitumor activity against s.c.-implanted colon 38 (murine colon adenocarcinoma). I(R=MeO, X=N, Y-COH) has a broad range of EDs. This compd. inhibited mitosis of P388 cells at cytotoxic concns.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK38Xlt1CjurY%253D&md5=db633c17bf3dae2ae30c689e3580709e

          Pyrazolopyrimidine-2,4-dione Sulfonamides: Novel and Selective Calcitonin Inducers
          Gilbert, Adam M.; Caltabiano, Stephen; Koehn, Frank E.; Chen, Zhen-jia; Francisco, Gerardo D.; Ellingboe, John W.; Kharode, Yogendra; Mangine, AnnaMarie; Francis, Rita; TrailSmith, Mark; Gralnick, David
          Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2002), 45 (11), 2342-2345CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
          A series of pyrazolo[4,3-d]pyrimidine sulfonamides and pyrazolo[3,4-d]pyrimidine sulfonamides have been prepd. These compds. increase transcription of a calcitonin-luciferase promoter and prodn. of cellular calcitonin in a calcitonin-secretion/RIA assay with minimized phosphodiesterase type 4 inhibitory activity at 30 μM as compared to structurally related xanthine methylene ketones such as denbufyllene. These two series are notable examples of small mols. that act as CT-inducers, a method to potentially treat bone loss diseases.

        34. 34
          (a) Shi, F.; Tse, M. K.; Zhou, S.; Pohl, M. M.; Radnik, J.; Hübner, S.; Jahnisch, K.; Brückner, A.; Beller, M. Green and efficient synthesis of sulfonamides catalyzed by nano-Ru/Fe3O4. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 1775– 1779,  DOI: 10.1021/ja807681v
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          34a
          Green and Efficient Synthesis of Sulfonamides Catalyzed by Nano-Ru/Fe3O4
          Shi, Feng; Tse, Man Kin; Zhou, Shaolin; Pohl, Marga-Martina; Radnik, Joerg; Huebner, Sandra; Jaehnisch, Klaus; Brueckner, Angelika; Beller, Matthias
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (5), 1775-1779CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          The environmentally benign synthesis of carbon-nitrogen bonds continues to be an active and challenging field of chem. research. Here, a novel, environmentally benign method for the direct coupling of sulfonamides and alcs. is described. Despite the importance of sulfonamide derivs. as intermediates in drug synthesis, till now such transformations are rarely known. For the first time a domino dehydrogenation-condensation-hydrogenation sequence of alcs. and sulfonamides has been realized in the presence of a nanostructured catalyst. The magnetic property of the catalyst system allows for convenient isolation of the product and efficient recycling of the catalyst. A variety of coupling reactions of benzylic alcs. and sulfonamides including various heterocycles were successfully realized, often with >80% isolated yield. Advantageously, only one equiv. of the primary alc. is consumed in the process. Mechanistic investigations of the competitive reactions of benzyl alc. and d7-benzyl alc. with p-toluenesulfonamide revealed a kinetic isotope effect (kH/kD) of 2.86 (±0.109) for the dehydrogenation of benzyl alc. and 0.74 (±0.021) for the hydrogenation of N-benzylidene-p-toluenesulfonamide intermediate, which suggests dehydrogenation of the alc. to be the rate detg. step.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtVejtb0%253D&md5=730cf468c9c01ea9d463190f9dff5233
          open URL

          (b) Moore, J. D.; Herpel, R. H.; Lichtsinn, J. R.; Flynn, D. L.; Hanson, P. R. ROMP-generated oligomeric sulfonyl chlorides as versatile soluble scavenging agents. Org. Lett. 2003, 5, 105– 107,  DOI: 10.1021/ol0270273
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          34b
          ROMP-Generated Oligomeric Sulfonyl Chlorides as Versatile Soluble Scavenging Agents
          Moore, Joel D.; Herpel, Russell H.; Lichtsinn, Joy R.; Flynn, Daniel L.; Hanson, Paul R.
          Organic Letters (2003), 5 (2), 105-107CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
          A new method for homogeneous nucleophilic scavenging employing oligomeric sulfonyl chloride (OSC) reagents is described. The method utilizes OSC to rapidly scavenge a variety of amines that are present in excess. The OSC reagents are generated from ROM polymn. of 2-chlorosulfonyl-5-norbornene utilizing the second generation Grubbs catalyst to produce oligomers of varying size as stable, free-flowing powders. Following the scavenging event, these oligomers are pptd. with Et acetate leaving products in excellent yield and purity.

          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xpsl2jurg%253D&md5=d666e20701250edbd91b11d925b07a05

          Devendar, P.; Yang, G. F. Sulfur-containing agrochemicals. Top. Curr. Chem. 2017, 375, 82  DOI: 10.1007/s41061-017-0169-9
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          35
          Sulfur-Containing Agrochemicals
          Devendar Ponnam; Yang Guang-Fu
          Topics in current chemistry (Cham) (2017), 375 (6), 82 ISSN:2365-0869.
          Modern agricultural chemistry has to support farmers by providing innovative agrochemicals. In this context, the introduction of sulfur atoms into an active ingredient is still an important tool in modulating the properties of new crop-protection compounds. More than 30% of today's agrochemicals contain at least one sulfur atom, mainly in fungicides, herbicides and insecticides. A number of recently developed sulfur-containing agrochemical candidates represent a novel class of chemical compounds with new modes of action, so we intend to highlight the emerging interest in commercially active sulfur-containing compounds. This chapter gives a comprehensive overview of selected leading sulfur-containing pesticidal chemical families namely: sulfonylureas, sulfonamides, sulfur-containing heterocyclics, thioureas, sulfides, sulfones, sulfoxides and sulfoximines. Also, the most suitable large-scale synthetic methods of the recently launched or provisionally approved sulfur-containing agrochemicals from respective chemical families have been highlighted.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1M%252FmvFShsw%253D%253D&md5=b2872c9b5e1461ee331247d828767bb6
          open URL

          (a) Wright, S. W.; Hallstrom, K. N. A Convenient preparation of heteroaryl sulfonamides and sulfonyl fluorides from heteroaryl thiols. J. Org. Chem. 2006, 71, 1080– 1084,  DOI: 10.1021/jo052164+
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          36a
          A convenient preparation of heteroaryl sulfonamides and sulfonyl fluorides from heteroaryl thiols
          Wright, Stephen W.; Hallstrom, Kelly N.
          Journal of Organic Chemistry (2006), 71 (3), 1080-1084CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
          Heteroarom. thiols may be oxidized to the sulfonyl chloride at low temp. (-25°) by using 3.3 equiv of aq. sodium hypochlorite. The reaction is rapid, avoids the use of chlorine gas, and succeeds with substrates that have previously been found to afford little or none of the sulfonamide product with other procedures. The method allows the prepn. of the sulfonyl fluorides, which are stable enough to be purified and stored, making them potentially useful monomers in parallel chem. efforts.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XjvV2lug%253D%253D&md5=6ee19d58ba35b16a827ecbda28a6b721

          36b
          Synthesis of sulfonamides and sulfonic esters via reaction of amines and phenols with thiols using H2O2-POCl3 system
          Bahrami, Kiumars; Khodaei, Mohammad M.; Abbasi, Jamshid
          Tetrahedron (2012), 68 (25), 5095-5101CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Ltd.)
          Phosphorus oxychloride efficiently promoted the synthesis of sulfonamides and sulfonic esters, e.g., I (X = NH or O; R1 = H, Me, F, Br, NO2; R2 = H, Me, MeO), from thiols with hydrogen peroxide in the presence of Amberlite IRA-400 (OH-). This method has been applied to a variety of substrates including nucleophilic and sterically hindered amines, and also phenols with excellent yields of sulfonamides and sulfonic esters. In most cases these reactions are highly selective, simple, and clean, affording products in excellent yields and high purity.

          (c) Goldberg, F. W.; Kettle, J. G.; Kogej, T.; Perry, M. W. D.; Tomkinson, N. P. Designing novel building blocks is an overlooked strategy to improve compound quality. Drug Discovery Today 2015, 20, 11– 17,  DOI: 10.1016/j.drudis.2014.09.023
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          36c
          Designing novel building blocks is an overlooked strategy to improve compound quality
          Goldberg Frederick W; Kettle Jason G; Tomkinson Nick P; Kogej Thierry; Perry Matthew W D
          Drug discovery today (2015), 20 (1), 11-7 ISSN:.
          One pragmatic way to improve compound quality, while enhancing and accelerating drug discovery projects, is the ability to access a high quality, novel, diverse building block collection. Here, we outline general principles that should be applied to ensure that a building block collection has the greatest impact on drug discovery projects, by discussing design principles for novel reagents and what types of reagents are popular with medicinal chemists in general. We initiated a program in 2009 to address this, which has already delivered three candidate drugs, and the success of that program provides evidence that focussing on building block design is a useful strategy for drug discovery.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2M7nt1aksA%253D%253D&md5=6abab9b017e3d115c1ac7ac6b0483bb9

          A metal-free and microwave-assisted efficient synthesis of diaryl sulfones
          Kumar, Dalip; Arun, V.; Pilania, Meenakshi; Shekar, K. P. Chandra
          Synlett (2013), 24 (7), 831-836CODEN: SYNLES; ISSN:0936-5214. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
          An efficient and general protocol for the synthesis of diaryl sulfones via the metal-free coupling of readily available diaryl-iodonium salts and arenesulfinates in PEG-400 under microwave irradn. has been developed. Utilizing this metal-free and eco-friendly protocol, we have prepd. various diaryl sulfones in high yields and shorter reaction times under mild conditions. Furthermore, the coupling of diaryliodonium with arenesulfinate salts with and without copper iodide provides a convenient access to various diaryl sulfones with high selectivity.

          DABSO-Based, Three-Component, One-Pot Sulfone Synthesis
          Deeming, Alex S.; Russell, Claire J.; Hennessy, Alan J.; Willis, Michael C.
          Organic Letters (2014), 16 (1), 150-153CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
          The addn. of Grignard reagents or organolithium reagents to the SO2-surrogate DABSO generates a diverse set of metal sulfinates, suitable for direct conversion to sulfone products. The metal sulfinates can be trapped in situ with a wide range of C-electrophiles, including alkyl, allyl, and benzyl halides, epoxides, and (hetero)aryliodoniums.

          Transition-Metal-Free C-S Bond Formation: A Facile Access to Aryl Sulfones from Sodium Sulfinates via Arynes
          Pandya, Virat G.; Mhaske, Santosh B.
          Organic Letters (2014), 16 (14), 3836-3839CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
          Sulfones have been attractive targets for synthetic org. chemists owing to their immense applications in medicinal, material, and synthetic chem. In this context, an efficient transition-metal-free process has been demonstrated, wherein a broad range of alkyl/aryl/heteroaryl sodium sulfinates react with varyingly substituted aryne precursors (o-silyl aryl triflates) under mild reaction conditions to afford structurally diverse sulfones in good to excellent yields. E.g., in the presence of TBAF in MeCN, reaction of 2-TMSC6H4OTf and PhS(O)ONa gave 94% Ph2SO2.

          37d
          Copper-Catalyzed Coupling of Oxime Acetates with Sodium Sulfinates: An Efficient Synthesis of Sulfone Derivatives
          Tang, Xiaodong; Huang, Liangbin; Xu, Yanli; Yang, Jidan; Wu, Wanqing; Jiang, Huanfeng
          Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2014), 53 (16), 4205-4208CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          Sulfone derivs. are important synthetic intermediates. However, the general method for their prepn. is through traditional coupling reaction: the alkylation of sodium sulfinates with phenacyl halides. Based on the authors' previous work on sodium sulfinates and oxime acetates, the authors herein report a novel method for sulfone derivs. by oxidative coupling with sodium sulfinates and oxime acetates using copper as catalyst. The sulfonylvinylamine products could be formed in excellent yields. Upon hydrolysis by silica gel in CH2Cl2, β-ketosulfones could also be efficiently constructed. Various sulfonylvinylamines and β-ketosulfones were obtained in good to excellent yields under the optimized reaction conditions. Mechanistic studies indicated that this transformation involved copper-catalyzed N-O bond cleavage, activation of a vinyl sp2 C-H bond, and C-S bond formation. The oxime acetates act as both a substrate and an oxidant, thus the reaction needs no addnl. oxidants or additives.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXjtVGlsbo%253D&md5=6497ad8daefa98f2297809e6afee6164

          Copper catalyzed synthesis of unsymmetrical diaryl sulfones from an arenediazonium salt and sodium p-toluenesulfinate
          Gund, Sitaram Haribhau; Shelkar, Radheshyam Suresh; Nagarkar, Jayashree Milind
          RSC Advances (2015), 5 (77), 62926-62930CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          Aryl sulfones have been for the first time synthesized by the reaction of sodium p-toluenesulfinate and arenediazonium salts using a CuI catalyzed homogeneous system. The developed protocol is a simple and efficient new route for the synthesis of diaryl sulfones with excellent product yields. The mild reaction conditions tolerate a range of functional groups. The best results were obtained with CuI, N,N'-dimethylethylenediamine, TBAI and K2CO3 in DMSO at 100 °C under an inert atm.

          38a
          Magnetically Separable Copper Ferrite Nanoparticles-Catalyzed Synthesis of Diaryl, Alkyl/Aryl Sulfones from Arylsulfinic Acid Salts and Organohalides/Boronic Acids
          Srinivas, B. T. V.; Rawat, Vikas S.; Konda, Kavitha; Sreedhar, Bojja
          Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis (2014), 356 (4), 805-817CODEN: ASCAF7; ISSN:1615-4150. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          A recyclable, inexpensive, non-toxic and environmentally benign catalytic system comprised of magnetically separable copper ferrite (CuFe2O4) nanoparticles was developed for the synthesis of diaryl, alkyl/aryl sulfones. Arylsulfinic acid salts are coupled with various alkyl/aryl halides/boronic acids to afford the corresponding diaryl, alkyl/aryl sulfones in good to excellent yields under the identical catalytic system. A wide range of functional group tolerance, with facile recovery of the catalyst by application of an external magnetic field, and consistently high catalytic efficiency for five consecutive cycles render the protocol operationally attractive.

          Application of fundamental organometallic chemistry to the development of a gold-catalyzed synthesis of sulfinate derivatives
          Johnson, Miles W.; Bagley, Scott W.; Mankad, Neal P.; Bergman, Robert G.; Mascitti, Vincent; Toste, F. Dean
          Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2014), 53 (17), 4404-4407CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          The development of a gold(I)-catalyzed sulfination of arylboronic acids is described. This transformation proceeds through an unprecedented mechanism which exploits the reactivity of Au(I)-heteroatom bonds to form sulfinate anions. Further in situ elaboration of the sulfinate intermediates leads to the corresponding sulfones and sulfonamides.

          A mild and efficient synthesis of diaryl sulfones from arylboronic acids and arylsulfonyl hydrazides is described.           (e) Debnath, S.; Mondal, S. Sultams: recent syntheses and applications. Eur. J. Org. Chem. 2018, 2018, 933– 956,  DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.201701491

          38e
          Sultams: Recent Syntheses and Applications
          Debnath, Sudarshan; Mondal, Shovan
          European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2018), 2018 (8), 933-956CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          A review. Sultams are very important scaffolds both in medicinal chem. and in synthetic org. chem. Very important methodologies for the asym. and non-asym. synthesis of sultams, including asym. synthesis with memory of chirality (MOC), have recently been developed. Nowadays sultams are tremendously widely applied both in the medicinal field and in the synthetic field for the synthesis of different natural and non-natural heterocycles. This review covers the recent development (2011-June 2017) of powerful methodologies for the synthesis of sultams and their applications in various fields during this period. A crit. view of the mechanisms of the developed methodologies together with the scope and limitations of these methods add an extra dimension to the text.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhsVGrtbY%253D&md5=a692c1c3de603ccafe00ba2ce3a14a17

          One-Pot Sonogashira Coupling-Cyclization toward Regioselective Synthesis of Benzosultams
          Debnath, Sudarshan; Mondal, Shovan
          Journal of Organic Chemistry (2015), 80 (8), 3940-3948CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
          A one-pot method for the Sonogashira coupling and cyclization of 2-bromobenzenesulfonamides and terminal alkynes is presented. This method allows access to a variety of substituted benzosultams regioselectively in excellent yields. The reasons for regioselectivity are interpreted through d. functional theory (DFT) studies.

          (g) Debnath, S.; Mondal, S. Regio-and stereoselective synthesis of benzo-δ-sultams by palladium-catalyzed hydrocarbonation of alkynes. Synthesis 2016, 48, 710– 722,  DOI: 10.1055/s-0035-1561288

          38g
          Regio- and Stereoselective Synthesis of Benzo-δ-sultams by Palladium-Catalyzed Hydrocarbonation of Alkynes
          Debnath, Sudarshan; Mondal, Shovan
          Synthesis (2016), 48 (5), 710-722CODEN: SYNTBF; ISSN:1437-210X. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
          An efficient method for the synthesis of benzo-δ-sultams [(4Z)-4-benzylidene-2-(arylmethyl)-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,2-benzothiazine 1,1-dioxides] I (R1 = Me, Et, Bn, pyridin-2-ylmethyl; R2 = H, Me, OMe, OEt, OBn) via palladium(0)-catalyzed hydrocarbonation of alkynes is presented. This method allows regioselective access to a variety of substituted benzosultams in excellent yields under mild conditions. The stereochem. of the exocyclic double bond of the benzosultam derivs. is confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

          Regioselective Synthesis of 1,2-Benzothiazine 1,1-Dioxide Derivatives by Intramolecular Heck Cyclization
          Debnath, Sudarshan; Malakar, Suniti; Mondal, Shovan
          Synthesis (2016), 48 (20), 3544-3550CODEN: SYNTBF; ISSN:1437-210X. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
          An efficient method for the synthesis of bioactive heterocycles contg. 1,2-benzothiazine 1,1-dioxide derivs. I (R = 1-naphthyl, 2-oxochromen-6-yl, 2H-1,3-benzodioxol-5-yl, etc.) via Pd-catalyzed intramol. Heck cyclization is reported. The method offers the regioselective synthesis of highly functionalized benzosultams I in 80-85% yields. The structure of benzosultam derivs. is confirmed from single crystal X-ray diffraction.

          Von Braun, J. Action of cyanogen bromide on tertiary amines. Ber. Dtsch. Chem. Ges. 1900, 33, 1438– 1452,  DOI: 10.1002/cber.19000330208
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          39
          Action of cyanogen bromide on tertiary amines
          von Braun, Julius
          Berichte der Deutschen Chemischen Gesellschaft (1900), 33 (), 1438-52CODEN: BDCGAS ISSN:.
          Cyanogen bromide reacts with tertiary amines, NR1R11R111. In some cases, the transient formation of a solid substance, presumably a compound, NR1R11R111Br.CN, can be observed; in all cases, the final products are a cyanamide, NR11R111.CN, and an alkyl bromide, R1I. In the case of dimethylaniline, and in this case only, the formation of a tetralkylammonium salt, NMe3PhBr, was observed in amount equivalent approximately to 2 mols. per 3 of the cyanamide; without doubt, the alkyl bromide, formed as indicated above, had added itself on to some of the tertiary amine which had not yet reacted with the cyanogen bromide. In the case of tripropylamine, ethyldipropylamine, methyldipropylamine, and tribenzylamine, the hydrobromide of the amine was formed in addition to the cyanamide. It is always the smallest of the alkyl radicles that is eliminated as the alkyl bromide; this was distilled off, and then the cyanamide was distilled over under diminished pressure. The latter was identified by hydrolysing it with acid agents into the corresponding secondary amine, NHR11R111, or by converting it with alcoholic ammonia and hydrogen sulphide into the corresponding thiocarbamide, NR11R111.CS.NH2. Methyldipropylamine, ethyldipropylamine, and tripropylamine react very vigorously with cyanogen bromide; ether may be used as a diluent. Dimethylaniline, methylethylaniline, and diethylaniline react less readily, and the first somewhat abnormally, as just indicated. Methylpropylaniline, ethylpropylaniline, and dipropylaniline react still less readily. Diphenylamine does react, but the reaction has to be accelerated by heating for 2 hours at 60-70°; the same is true of tribenzylamine. Diphenylmethylamine and triphenylamine do not react at all with cyanogen bromide. Most of the substances obtained seem to be known already. Phenylpropylcyanamide is, perhaps, new; it boils at 140-142° under 10 mm., and at 281° under atmospheric pressure, decomposing slightly in the latter case. By treating a tertiary amine with cyanogen bromide and hydrolysing the resulting cyanamide, the smallest radicle of the amine can be eliminated and a secondary amine obtained. The method is a convenient one, and may prove useful in the investigation of alkaloids.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaD28XhtVSju7s%253D&md5=7b3ff27f6ecc3d4da5e1106b19faa484
          open URL
        40. 40
          (a) Flynn, E. H.; Murphy, H. W.; McMahon, R. E. Erythromycin. II. des-N-methylerythromycin and N-methyl-C14-erythromycin. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1955, 77, 3104– 3106,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01616a051
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          40a
          Erythromycin. II. De-N-methylerythromycin and N-methyl-C14-erythromycin
          Flynn, Edwin H.; Murphy, Hubert W.; McMahon, Robert E.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (1955), 77 (), 3104-6CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
          cf. C.A. 49, 8934e. Erythromycin (I) has been converted to O,N-dicarbobenzyloxyde-N-methylerythromycin (II) which was hydrogenolyzed to give de-N-methylerythromycin (III). III was converted further to N-methyl-C14-erythromycin (IV). PhCH2O2CCl (100 cc.) and 74 g. dry NaHCO3 treated with vigorous stirring with 50 g. I in 5-g. portions during about 1 hr. at 35-50° with intermittent cooling, an addnl. 50-cc. portion PhCH2O2CCl added after about 75% of the I had been added, the mixt. stirred 1 hr. at room temp., dild. with 250 cc. C6H6, and filtered, the residual solid washed with 200 cc. C6H6, the combined filtrate and washings shaken with cooling with four 120-cc. portions cold 0.25N HCl (a gummy substance thought to be O-carbobenzyloxy-I.HCl was formed with each of the first 3 acid washes, but remained in the aq. layer), washed with two 120-cc. portions H2O, dried, and evapd. in vacuo, the residue dissolved in 50 cc. CHCl3, the soln. treated with 120 cc. Et2O, dild. gradually with 1200 cc. Skellysolve B, allowed to stand several hrs., and filtered, and the residue air-dried yielded 38.1 g. II, m. 193-4°. Alternatively, the reaction mixt. was filtered after the addn. of the PhCH2OCOCl was completed, the filtrate dild. with petr. ether to completely ppt. the product, the ppt. dissolved in 50% MeOH contg. 0.1% NaHCO3, the soln. heated 4 hrs. at 40° and evapd. in vacuo, the residue dissolved in CHCl3, the soln. extd. with 5 equal vols. phosphate buffer, pH 6.0, washed with H2O, dried, and evapd. in vacuo, and the solid residue recrystd. from Me2CO by adding cyclohexane gave II. II (116 g.) in 2.3 l. 95% EtOH treated with 500 cc. H2O contg. 16.5 g. NaOAc, 100 cc. 50% EtOH contg. 10.4 cc. glacial AcOH, and 3.0 g. Pd black, the mixt. treated with stirring 24 hrs. with H, filtered, and concd. in vacuo to about 300 cc., the residue dild. with 2.5 l. H2O, the mixt. warmed, then cooled, adjusted dropwise with stirring below 5° (ice cooling) with 2.5N NaOH to pH 10.3, warmed to room temp. during 6 hrs. with occasional stirring, kept 1 hr. at 35°, and filtered, and the filter residue washed with 50 cc. warm H2O and dried gave 61.0 g. III; the filtrate cooled, again adjusted to pH 10.3, and kept overnight at 48° gave an addnl. 10.0 g. III. Crude III (59 g.) dissolved in 200 cc. refluxing Me2CO and kept overnight at 5°, and the solid deposit dried 2 hrs. at 56° gave 49.0 g. pure III, m. 140-5°; it assayed 54 mcg./mg. of I activity; the soly. of III increased in H2O with decreasing temp. III (1.00 g.) in 50 cc. MeOH treated dropwise at 2° with 0.35 cc. Ac2O, the mixt. kept 3 hrs. at 2° and evapd. in vacuo, the residual amorphous solid dissolved in 4 cc. CHCl3, and the soln. dild. with 14 cc. petr. ether gave the N-Ac deriv. of III, m. 207-9° (dried 2 hrs. at 100°); it was microbiologically inactive; when dried at 78° in vacuo, it analyzed for a monohydrate. III (740 mg.), 35 cc. abs. EtOH, 225 mg. Pd black, and 3 cc. 1% aq. C14H2O (0.001 mole contg. 1 millicurie C14) stirred 48 hrs. at 28° and atm. pressure under H, the mixt. treated with 1 mg. ordinary CH2O and 50 mg. Pd black, again hydrogenated 24 hrs., and centrifuged, the supernatant evapd. to dryness in vacuo, the residue treated with 15 cc. H2O, kept 24 hrs. at -20°, and warmed to 60°, and the ppt. filtered off and dried yielded 300 mg. anhyd. IV, specific activity 1.1 μc./mg., bioactivity 980 γ/mg. IV chromatographed on paper showed about 99% of the bioactivity to be assocd. with I, the remainder with erythromycin B; the mother liquor from the IV evapd. to dryness gave an addnl. 315 mg. IV, specific activity 1.1 μc./mg., bioactivity 620 γ/mg.

          (b) Morimoto, S.; Misawa, Y.; Adachi, T.; Nagate, T.; Watanabe, Y.; Omura, S. Chemical modification of erythromycins. J. Antibiot. 1990, 43, 286– 294,  DOI: 10.7164/antibiotics.43.286
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          40b
          Chemical modification of erythromycins. II. Synthesis and antibacterial activity of O-alkyl derivatives of erythromycin A
          Morimoto, Shigeo; Misawa, Yoko; Adachi, Takashi; Nagate, Takatoshi; Watanabe, Yoshiaki; Omura, Sadafumi
          Journal of Antibiotics (1990), 43 (3), 286-94CODEN: JANTAJ; ISSN:0021-8820.
          A series of O-alkyl erythromycin A derivs. I and II (R = R2 = R3 = H, Me; R1 = H, Me, Et, Pr) have been synthesized and their antibacterial activities compared with those of erythromycin A (I, R-R3 = H) and 6-O-methylerythromycin A (I, R = Me, R1-R3 = H). Methylation of the hydroxyl groups of erythromycin A proceeded stepwise by two main pathways beginning at C-6 and C-11, resp. O-Alkylation, other than methylation, took place at the C-11 hydroxyl group exclusively. I (R = R2 = Me, R1 = R3 = H) showed comparable in vitro antibacterial activity to I (R = H, Me, R1-R3 = H; R = R2 = R3 = H, R1 = Me) was slightly less active than I (R-R3 = H). O-Methylation at the C-4" position resulted in a decrease of antibacterial activity.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3cXlslamt7k%253D&md5=0a0bd1697e242aa5ab1fb78746e4de73

          (c) Peat, A. J.; Buchwald, S. L. Novel syntheses of tetrahydropyrroloquinolines: Applications to alkaloid synthesis. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1996, 118, 1028– 1030,  DOI: 10.1021/ja953080t
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          40c
          Novel Syntheses of Tetrahydropyrroloquinolines: Applications to Alkaloid Synthesis
          Peat, Andrew J.; Buchwald, Stephen L.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (1996), 118 (5), 1028-30CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Two novel routes involving the intramol. olefin insertion with a zirconium-benzyne complex, followed by a palladium-catalyzed aryl amination, were developed for the synthesis of tetrahydropyrroloquinolines. In one approach, exemplified in the six-step total synthesis of the South American toad poison dehydrobufotenine, the tricyclic system was formed via the Pd-catalyzed ring closure of a functionalized tryptamine deriv. In the second, cyclization of an appropriately substituted quinoline yields I, an intermediate in the synthesis of damirones A and B, and also makaluvamine C, a topoisomerase II inhibitor exhibiting antitumor properties.

          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          40d
          Ruthenium-catalyzed cytochrome P-450 type oxidation of tertiary amines with alkyl hydroperoxides
          Murahashi, Shunichi; Naota, Takeshi; Yonemura, Koichi
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (1988), 110 (24), 8256-8CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
          The Ru-catalyzed reaction of RR1NMe (R = Ph, 4-MeC6H4, 4-BrC6H4, 4-ClC6H4; R1 = Me, Et, CH2CH2CO2Me, CH2CH2CH:CH2) with Me3COOH gave 78-93% RR1NCH2OOCMe3 (I). Hydrolysis of I with 2N HCl in Et2O at room temp. gave 61-87% RR1NH. This is the first synthetically practical method for the N-demethylation of tertiary methylamines. Me groups are removed chemoselectively in the presence of various alkyl groups. This reaction provides a novel, biomimetic method for the construction of piperidine skeletons from N-methylhomoallylamines via olefin-iminium ion cyclizations reactions. Thus, the Ru-catalyzed oxidn. of PhNMeCH2CH2CH:CH2 gave 87% peroxide, which was converted to 1-phenyl-4-chloropiperidine (77%) on treatment with 2N HCl.
          >> More from SciFinder ®

          Stenmark, Heather G.; Brazzale, Antony; Ma, Zhenkun

          The use of N-iodosuccinimide as a selective N-demethylating agent under mild conditions have been described. These conditions were successfully applied to the synthesis of metabolites of potent antibacterial agents within the macrolide and ketolide classes. The conditions developed in the present studies should be applicable to other syntheses where selective N-demethylation is required.

          41b
          Efficient N-Demethylation of Opiate Alkaloids Using a Modified Nonclassical Polonovski Reaction
          McCamley, Kristy; Ripper, Justin A.; Singer, Robert D.; Scammells, Peter J.
          Journal of Organic Chemistry (2003), 68 (25), 9847-9850CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
          A modified Polonovski reaction has been employed to N-demethylate several opiate alkaloids in moderate to high yield. This method provides an alternative to traditional N-demethylation procedures which utilize toxic reagents such as cyanogen bromide or expensive reagents such as vinyl chloroformate. The current synthesis involves N-oxide formation, isolation of the corresponding N-oxide hydrochloride, and an FeSO4·7H2O mediated Polonovski reaction to afford the desired secondary amine.

          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          41c
          Further investigation of the N-demethylation of tertiary amine alkaloids using the non-classical Polonovski reaction
          Thavaneswaran, Shanti; Scammells, Peter J.
          Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2006), 16 (11), 2868-2871CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
          The iron salt-mediated Polonovski reaction efficiently N-demethylates certain opiate alkaloids. In this process, the use of the hydrochloride salt of the tertiary N-Me amine oxide was reported to give better yields of the desired N-demethylated product. Herein, we report further investigation into the use of N-oxide salts in the iron salt-mediated Polonovski reaction. An efficient approach for the removal of iron salts using TPPS that greatly facilitates isolation and purifn. of the N-nor product is also described.

          (d) Sako, M. M.; Shimada, K.; Hirota, K.; Maki, Y. Photochemical oxygen-atom transfer reaction by heterocycle N-oxides involving a single-electron transfer process: oxidative demethylation of N,N-dimethylaniline. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1986, 108, 6039– 6041,  DOI: 10.1021/ja00279a063
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          41d
          Photochemical oxygen-atom transfer reaction by heterocycle N-oxides involving a single-electron transfer process: oxidative demethylation of N,N-dimethylaniline
          Sako, Magoichi; Shimada, Kaoru; Hirota, Kosaku; Maki, Yoshifumi
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (1986), 108 (19), 6039-41CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
          PhNMe2 undergoes photochem. oxidative demethylation (to PhNHMe and HCHO) by heterocyclic N-oxides pyrimido[5,4-g]pteridine N-oxide I, isoxaloxazine N-oxide II, pyridine N-oxide, quinoline N-oxide, 4-nitropyridine N-oxide and 4-nitroquinoline N-oxide; the ease of the reaction depended on the N-oxide structure. Kinetics support a reaction which is initiated by the formation of a ground state N-oxide-PhNMe2 charge-transfer complex followed by single-electron transfer (SET) from PhNMe2 to the N-oxide in the exciplex. This mechanism formally parallels the SET mechanism for cytochrome P 450 catalyzed N-dealkylation and as such serves as an alternative to processes involving active O species, e.g., oxene of oxazilidine.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL28XlsFagurw%253D&md5=f008387106b70923e5a7719a55702e5d
          open URL
          .
          (e) Ripper, J. A.; Tiekink, E. R. T.; Scammells, P. Photochemical N-demethylation of alkaloids. Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2001, 11, 443– 445,  DOI: 10.1016/S0960-894X(00)00690-9
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          41e
          Photochemical N-demethylation of alkaloids
          Ripper, J. A.; Tiekink, E. R. T.; Scammells, P. J.
          Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2001), 11 (4), 443-445CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
          Certain alkaloids were obsd. to undergo N-demethylation processes under photochem. conditions. Tropine, acetyltropine, tropinone, and atropine were cleanly N-demethylated upon treatment with tetraphenylporphin, oxygen, and light. Dextromethorphan also underwent a N-demethylation reaction, but reacted further to afford an imine. In contrast, 14-acyloxycodeinones underwent a photochem. induced tandem N-demethylation-acyl migration.

          A General, Selective, High-Yield N-Demethylation Procedure for Tertiary Amines by Solid Reagents in a Convenient Column Chromatography-like Setup
          Rosenau, Thomas; Hofinger, Andreas; Potthast, Antje; Kosma, Paul
          Organic Letters (2004), 6 (4), 541-544CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
          A traditional preparative chromatog. column can be used to achieve quant. N-demethylation of tertiary N-methylamines and alkaloids. The filling is the crucial part and is loaded with different solid reagents in three reaction zones. The parent compd. is charged on the column, and the neat N-demethylated secondary amine leaves the column some minutes later.

          42
          Eosin Y-Sensitized Photocatalytic Reaction of Tertiary Aliphatic Amines with Arenesulfonyl Chlorides under Visible-Light Irradiation
          Cai, Yuguo; Zhang, Ronghua; Sun, Deli; Xu, Song; Zhou, Qiguang
          Synlett (2017), 28 (13), 1630-1635CODEN: SYNLES; ISSN:0936-5214. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
          A mild, practical, and environmentally friendly route to vinyl sulfones and sulfonamides has been developed based on the reaction of aliph. amines with arenesulfonyl chlorides in the presence of eosin Y as a photocatalyst under visible light. The method permits the selective formation of vinyl sulfones or sulfonamides, depending on the oxidn. environment and solvent. A wide range of products were obtained in moderate to good yields under the optimized conditions.

          Experimental and Calculated Electrochemical Potentials of Common Organic Molecules for Applications to Single-Electron Redox Chemistry
          Roth, Hudson G.; Romero, Nathan A.; Nicewicz, David A.
          Synlett (2016), 27 (5), 714-723CODEN: SYNLES; ISSN:0936-5214. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
          Herein, we report half-peak potentials for over 180 org. substrates obtained via cyclic voltammetry. These values are of great use in assessing the thermodn. of an electron-transfer process. In addn., we disclose a simple computational method to det. redox potentials of org. substrates.
          >> More from SciFinder ®

          Cherevatskaya, M.; Neumann, M.; Fuldner, S.; Harlander, C.; Kummel, S.; Dankesreiter, S.; Pfitzner, A.; Zeitler, K.; Kçnig, B.           [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          44
          Visible-Light-Promoted Stereoselective Alkylation by Combining Heterogeneous Photocatalysis with Organocatalysis
          Cherevatskaya, Maria; Neumann, Matthias; Fueldner, Stefan; Harlander, Christoph; Kuemmel, Susanne; Dankesreiter, Stephan; Pfitzner, Arno; Zeitler, Kirsten; Koenig, Burkhard
          Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2012), 51 (17), 4062-4066, S4062/1-S4062/18CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          The authors demonstrate that the combination of stereoselective organocatalysis with visible-light heterogeneous photoredox catalysis promotes the stereoselective formation of carbon-carbon bonds in good selectivity and yield. The approach combines the advantages of heterogeneous catalysis (robust, simple, and easy-to- sep. catalyst material) with the stereoselectivity achieved in homogeneous organocatalysis. The enantioselective α-alkylation of aldehydes developed was selected as a test reaction to apply inorg. heterogeneous photocatalysts. The following semiconductors were used: com. available white TiO2, the same material surface-modified covalently with a Phos-Texas Red dye to increase absorption of visible light (Phos-Texas-Red-TiO2), yellow PbBiO2Br, which absorbs blue light, and PbBiO2Br as bulk material and in nanocryst.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XjvVWqurc%253D&md5=89e792a2509ad731970b98c2d76083e6
          open URL

          Visible light-mediated dehydrogenative β-arylsulfonylation of tertiary aliphatic amines with arylsulfonyl chlorides
          Chen, Min; Huang, Zhi-Tang; Zheng, Qi-Yu
          Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2014), 12 (46), 9337-9340CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          The novel synthesis of β-arylsulfonyl enamines has been achieved by visible light-mediated dehydrogenative arylsulfonylation of tertiary aliph. amines with arylsulfonyl chlorides in moderate yield. E.g., in presence of Ru(bpy)3(PF6)2 in acetone under visible light irradn. in air, dehydrogenative β-arylsulfonylation of Et3N with 4-MeC6H4SO2Cl gave 47% (E)-N,N-diethyl-2-tosylethenamine (I).

        46. 46
          (a) Zhu, S.; Das, A.; Bui, L.; Zhou, H.; Curran, D. P.; Rueping, M. Oxygen switch in visible-light photoredox catalysis: radical additions and cyclizations and unexpected C–C-bond cleavage reactions. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2013, 135, 1823– 1829,  DOI: 10.1021/ja309580a
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          46a
          Oxygen Switch in Visible-Light Photoredox Catalysis: Radical Additions and Cyclizations and Unexpected C-C-Bond Cleavage Reactions
          Zhu, Shaoqun; Das, Arindam; Bui, Lan; Zhou, Hanjun; Curran, Dennis P.; Rueping, Magnus
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (5), 1823-1829CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Visible light photoredox catalyzed inter- and intramol. C-H functionalization reactions of tertiary amines have been developed. Oxygen was found to act as chem. switch to trigger two different reaction pathways and to obtain two different types of products from the same starting material. In the absence of oxygen, the intermol. addn. of N,N-dimethylanilines to electron-deficient alkenes provided γ-amino nitriles in good to high yields. In the presence of oxygen, a radical addn./cyclization reaction occurred which resulted in the formation of tetrahydroquinoline derivs. in good yields under mild reaction conditions. The intramol. version of the radical addn. led to the unexpected formation of indole-3-carboxaldehyde derivs. Mechanistic investigations of this reaction cascade uncovered a new photoredox catalyzed C-C bond cleavage reaction.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtFCnsLg%253D&md5=5688f02f1aa58f578f0f3a02da983476
          open URL
          .
          (b) Tang, J.; Grampp, G.; Liu, Y.; Wang, B. X.; Tao, F. F.; Wang, L. J.; Liang, X. Z.; Xiao, H. Q.; Shen, Y. M. Visible light mediated cyclization of tertiary anilines with maleimides using nickel (II) oxide surface-modified titanium dioxide catalyst. J. Org. Chem. 2015, 80, 2724– 2732,  DOI: 10.1021/jo502901h
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          46b
          Visible Light Mediated Cyclization of Tertiary Anilines with Maleimides Using Nickel(II) Oxide Surface-Modified Titanium Dioxide Catalyst
          Tang, Jian; Grampp, Gunter; Liu, Yun; Wang, Bing-Xiang; Tao, Fei-Fei; Wang, Li-Jun; Liang, Xue-Zheng; Xiao, Hui-Quan; Shen, Yong-Miao
          Journal of Organic Chemistry (2015), 80 (5), 2724-2732CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
          Surface-modified titanium dioxides by highly dispersed NiO particles have an extended absorption in the visible light region and a reduced hole-electron pair recombination than unmodified TiO2. They have now been successfully applied as highly active heterogeneous photocatalysts in the visible light mediated direct cyclization of tertiary anilines with maleimides to give tetrahydroquinoline products in moderate to high yields at ambient temp. In contrast with unmodified titanium dioxide catalysts that are conventionally used in a stoichiometric amt. in combination with UVA light, only a catalytic amt. (1 mol %) of the surface-modified TiO2 catalyst is needed along with visible light to efficiently catalyze the reaction. Compared with transition-metal complexes such as Ru(bpy)3Cl2 or Ir(ppy)2(dtbbpy)PF6, advantages of these surface-modified titanium dioxides as photocatalyst include high catalytic activity, low cost, ease of recovering, and being able to be used for at least nine times without significant decay of catalytic activity.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFeht7g%253D&md5=e1ae95210815d275c098e7861714bece
          open URL

          N-Hydroxyphthalimide: A new photoredox catalyst for [4+1] radical cyclization of N-methylanilines with isocyanides
          Yadav, Arvind K.; Yadav, Lal Dhar S.
          Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2016), 52 (70), 10621-10624CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          The first utilization of N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) as an organophotoredox catalyst is demonstrated by the [4+1] radical cyclization reaction of N-methylanilines with isocyanides. The protocol offers an operationally simple one-pot synthesis of 3-iminodihydroindoles at room temp.

          46d
          Visible-light mediated heterogeneous C-H functionalization: oxidative multi-component reactions using a recyclable titanium dioxide (TiO2) catalyst
          Vila, Carlos; Rueping, Magnus

          Visible-light mediated heterogeneous C-H functionalization of tertiary amines provides access to a variety of α-amino amides. An oxidative, titanium dioxide catalyzed, Ugi-type, three-component reaction has been developed in which the catalyst can be recycled without loss of activity.

          47c
          Synthesis, Anti-Inflammatory Activity, and in Vitro Antitumor Effect of a Novel Class of Cyclooxygenase Inhibitors: 4-(Aryloyl)phenyl Methyl Sulfones
          Harrak, Youssef; Casula, Giovanni; Basset, Joan; Rosell, Gloria; Plescia, Salvatore; Raffa, Demetrio; Cusimano, Maria Grazia; Pouplana, Ramon; Pujol, Maria Dolors
          Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2010), 53 (18), 6560-6571CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
          Following the previous research on anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), the design and synthesis of 4-(aryloyl)phenyl Me sulfones are reported. These substances were characterized for their capacity to inhibit cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2) isoenzymes. Mol. modeling studies showed that the methylsulfone group of these compds. was inserted deep in the pocket of the human COX-2 binding site, in an orientation that precludes hydrogen bonding with Arg120, Ser353, and Tyr355 through their oxygen atoms. The N-arylindole I was the most potent inhibitor of COX-2 and also the most selective (COX-1/COX-2 IC50 ratio was 262). The indole deriv. I was further tested in vivo for its anti-inflammatory activity in rats. I showed greater inhibitory activity than ibuprofen. Some other compds. showed strong activity against carrageenan-induced inflammation and weak capacity to inhibit the proliferation of human cell lines K562, NCI-H460, and HT-29 in vitro..
          >> More from SciFinder ®

          (d) Sun, Z. Y.; Botros, E.; Su, A. D.; Kim, Y.; Wang, E.; Baturay, N. Z.; Kwon, C. H. Sulfoxide-containing aromatic nitrogen mustards as hypoxia-directed bioreductive cytotoxins. J. Med. Chem. 2000, 43, 4160– 4168,  DOI: 10.1021/jm9904957
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          47d
          Sulfoxide-Containing Aromatic Nitrogen Mustards as Hypoxia-Directed Bioreductive Cytotoxins
          Sun, Zhong-Yue; Botros, Emad; Su, Ai-Duen; Kim, Yu; Wang, Enju; Baturay, Nesrine Z.; Kwon, Chul-Hoon
          Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2000), 43 (22), 4160-4168CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
          A series of diaryl and alkylaryl sulfoxide-contg. nitrogen mustards were synthesized and evaluated for their hypoxia-selective cytotoxicity against V-79 cells in vitro as well as for their metab. profiles with the rat S-9 fractions. In general, the diaryl sulfoxides (4, 5, and 7-9) showed much greater hypoxia selectivity (11-27-fold) than the alkylaryl sulfoxides (∼3-fold) (1 and 3). The fused di-Ph sulfoxides (10 and 11), on the other hand, showed very low hypoxia selectivity (1.3-3-fold). Compd. 10 was highly cytotoxic under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions, while 11 showed low cytotoxicity under both conditions. The bioredn. of 8 by the rat S-9 fraction under anaerobic conditions was inhibited by menadione and enhanced by benzaldehyde, acetaldehyde, or 2-hydroxypyrimidine suggesting the involvement of aldehyde oxidase in the redn. of the sulfoxides. Bioreductive metab. studies of selected model sulfoxides suggested that diaryl sulfoxides are better substrates for aldehyde oxidase than alkylaryl sulfoxides.

          47e
          Novel Indolyl Aryl Sulfones Active against HIV-1 Carrying NNRTI Resistance Mutations: Synthesis and SAR Studies
          Silvestri, Romano; De Le Martino, Gabriella; La Regina, Giuseppe; Artico, Marino; Massa, Silvio; Vargiu, Laura; Mura, Massimo; Loi, Anna Giulia; Marceddu, Tiziana; La Colla, Paolo
          Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2003), 46 (12), 2482-2493CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
          The potent anti-HIV-1 activities of L-737,126 (I) and PAS sulfones prompted us to design and test against HIV-1 in acutely infected MT-4 cells a no. of novel 1- and 3-benzenesulfonylindoles. Indoles belonging to the 1-benzenesulfonyl series were found poorly or totally inactive. On the contrary, some of the 3-benzenesulfonyl derivs. turned out to be as potent as I, being endowed with potencies in the low nanomolar concn. range. In particular, (2-methylphenyl)sulfonyl and (3-methylphenyl)sulfonyl derivs. showed EC50 values of 1 nM. Introduction of two Me groups at positions 3 and 5 of the Ph ring of I furnished derivs. which showed very potent and selective anti-HIV-1 activity not only against the wt strain, but also against mutants carrying NNRTI-resistant mutations at positions 103 and 181 of the reverse transcriptase gene.

          47f
          Folate-Synthesizing Enzyme System as Target for Development of Inhibitors and Inhibitor Combinations against Candida albicans-Synthesis and Biological Activity of New 2,4-Diaminopyrimidines and 4'-Substituted 4-Aminodiphenyl Sulfones
          Otzen, Thomas; Wempe, Ellen G.; Kunz, Brigitte; Bartels, Rainer; Lehwark-Yvetot, Gudrun; Haensel, Wolfram; Schaper, Klaus-Juergen; Seydel, Joachim K.
          Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2004), 47 (1), 240-253CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
          The design, synthesis, and testing of inhibitors of folate-synthesizing enzymes and of whole cell cultures of Candida albicans is described. The target enzymes used were dihydropteroic acid synthase (SYN) and dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). Several series of 2,4-diaminopyrimidines were synthesized and tested as inhibitors of DHFR and compared with their activity against DHFR derived from mycobacteria and Escherichia coli. To test for selectivity, also rat DHFR was used. A series of substituted 4-aminodiphenyl sulfones was tested for inhibitory activity against SYN and the I50 values compared to those obtained previously against Plasmodium berghei- and E. coli-derived SYN. Surprisingly, QSAR equations show very similar structural dependencies. To find an explanation for the large difference in the I50 values obsd. for enzyme inhibition (SYN, DHFR) and for inhibition of cell cultures of Candida, mutant strains with overexpressed efflux pumps and strains in which such pumps are deleted were included in the study and the MICs compared. Efflux pumps were responsible for the low activity of some of the tested derivs., others showed no increase in activity after pumps were knocked out. In this case it may be speculated that these derivs. are not able to enter the cells.

          Visible-Light Photoredox-Catalyzed Aminosulfonylation of Diaryliodonium Salts with Sulfur Dioxide and Hydrazines
          Liu, Nai-Wei; Liang, Shuai; Manolikakes, Georg
          Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis (2017), 359 (8), 1308-1319CODEN: ASCAF7; ISSN:1615-4150. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          A photoredox-catalyzed three-component synthesis of N-aminosulfonamides starting from diaryliodonium salts, hydrazines and sulfur dioxide is reported. This reaction proceeds under mild conditions at room temp. and is driven by visible light. A simple bisulfite salt can be used as a readily available and easy-to-handle sulfur dioxide source. Mechanistic studies support a catalytic photoredox pathway with the diaryliodonium salt as convenient source for aryl radicals.

          Lipophilicity behavior of model and medicinal compounds containing a sulfide, sulfoxide, or sulfone moiety
          Caron, Giulia; Gaillard, Patrick; Carrupt, Pierre Alain; Testa, Bernard
          Helvetica Chimica Acta (1997), 80 (2), 449-462CODEN: HCACAV; ISSN:0018-019X. (Verlag Helvetica Chimica Acta)
          This study was designed to unravel lipophilicity changes assocd. with the oxidn. state of the S-atom in model compds., drugs, and metabolites, special attention being given both to intermol. and intramol. effects. The methods used were exptl. (potentiometry, CPC, and shake-flask techniques to measure lipophilicity, 13C-NMR spectroscopy to investigate tautomeric equil.) and computational (quenched mol. dynamics and mol. lipophilicity potential). Simple, monofunctional model compds. were used to assess intermol. forces, as revealed by the Δlog Poct-alk and Δlog Poct-chf parameters. Drugs and their metabolites proved to be good probes to study intramol. effects in both neutral and anionic forms, as revealed by the difference between calcd. and exptl. log Poct values (the diff(log Pexp-calc) parameter). Sulindac and its metabolites showed a normal partitioning behavior, whereas the lipophilicity of sulfinpyrazone and its metabolites was markedly affected by tautomeric and conformational equil.

          48e
          Sulfoxide-Containing Aromatic Nitrogen Mustards as Hypoxia-Directed Bioreductive Cytotoxins
          Sun, Zhong-Yue; Botros, Emad; Su, Ai-Duen; Kim, Yu; Wang, Enju; Baturay, Nesrine Z.; Kwon, Chul-Hoon
          Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2000), 43 (22), 4160-4168CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
          A series of diaryl and alkylaryl sulfoxide-contg. nitrogen mustards were synthesized and evaluated for their hypoxia-selective cytotoxicity against V-79 cells in vitro as well as for their metab. profiles with the rat S-9 fractions. In general, the diaryl sulfoxides (4, 5, and 7-9) showed much greater hypoxia selectivity (11-27-fold) than the alkylaryl sulfoxides (∼3-fold) (1 and 3). The fused di-Ph sulfoxides (10 and 11), on the other hand, showed very low hypoxia selectivity (1.3-3-fold). Compd. 10 was highly cytotoxic under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions, while 11 showed low cytotoxicity under both conditions. The bioredn. of 8 by the rat S-9 fraction under anaerobic conditions was inhibited by menadione and enhanced by benzaldehyde, acetaldehyde, or 2-hydroxypyrimidine suggesting the involvement of aldehyde oxidase in the redn. of the sulfoxides. Bioreductive metab. studies of selected model sulfoxides suggested that diaryl sulfoxides are better substrates for aldehyde oxidase than alkylaryl sulfoxides.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXms1Oltbs%253D&md5=27015de01c3204605d6ecbed6fdfc846
          open URL
        49. 49
          Arepalli, S. K.; Choi, Y.; Lee, K.; Kang, J. S.; Jung, J. K.; Lee, H. Transition-metal-free, atom-economical cascade synthesis of novel 2-sulfonated-benzo [f][1,7] naphthyridines and their cytotoxic activities. Tetrahedron 2018, 74, 1646– 1654,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tet.2018.02.023
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          49
          Transition-metal-free, atom-economical cascade synthesis of novel 2-sulfonated-benzo[f][1,7]naphthyridines and their cytotoxic activities
          Arepalli, Sateesh Kumar; Choi, Yunseon; Lee, Kiho; Kang, Jong-Soon; Jung, Jae-Kyung; Lee, Heesoon
          Tetrahedron (2018), 74 (14), 1646-1654CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Ltd.)
          An efficient, transition-metal-free cascade synthetic method was developed for new 2-aryl/heteroaryl sulfonated benzo[f][1,7]naphthyridines. It is tert-Bu hydroperoxide (TBHP) mediated highly regioselective sulfonylation-cyclization-aromatization process between N-(3-aryl/heteroarylprop-2-yn-1-yl)quinolin-3-amines and aryl/heteroaryl sulfonylhydrazides. This synthetic protocol offers one-step strategy for C-S and C-C bond formations with a broad range of functional group tolerance. It is a simple, mild, and atom-economical route for the synthesis of various valuable functionalized 1, 2-aryl/heteroaryl sulfonated benzo[f][1,7]naphthyridines in moderate yields. Since the core motif of 2-sulfonated benzo[f][1,7]naphthyridines are biol. and pharmaceutically important (TLR activity 7, 8 modulators). Addnl., the synthesized derivs. were evaluated for their in vitro cytotoxic activities against six human cancer cell lines including lung (NCIH23), colon (HCT15), gastric (NUCG-3), renal (ACHN), prostate (PC-3), and breast (MDA-MB-231) cell lines. These compds. displayed significant cytotoxic activities against all tested human cancer cell lines.

          (a) Madasu, S. B.; Vekariaya, N. A.; Hari Kiran, M. N.; Gupta, B.; Islam, A.; Douglas, P. S.; Babu, K. R. Synthesis of compounds related to the anti-migraine drug eletriptan hydrobromide. Beilstein J. Org. Chem. 2012, 8, 1400– 1405,  DOI: 10.3762/bjoc.8.162
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          50a
          Synthesis of compounds related to the anti-migraine drug Eletriptan hydrobromide
          Madasu, Suri Babu; Vekariya, Nagaji Ambabhai; Hari Kiran, M. N. V. D.; Gupta, Badarinadh; Islam, Aminul; Douglas, Paul S.; Babu, Korupolu Raghu
          Beilstein Journal of Organic Chemistry (2012), 8 (), 1400-1405, No. 162CODEN: BJOCBH; ISSN:1860-5397. (Beilstein-Institut zur Foerderung der Chemischen Wissenschaften)
          Eletriptan hydrobromide is a selective serotonin (5-HT1) agonist, used for the acute treatment of the headache phase of migraine attacks. During the manuf. of Eletriptan hydrobromide the formation of various impurities were obsd. and identified by LC-MS. To control the formation of these impurities during the prepn. of active pharmaceutical ingredients, the structure of the impurities must be known. Major impurities of the Eletriptan hydrobromide synthesis were prepd. and characterized by using various spectroscopic techniques, i.e., mass spectroscopy, FTIR, 1H-NMR, 13C-NMR/DEPT and further confirmed by co-injection in HPLC. The present study will be of great help in the synthesis of highly pure Eletriptan hydrobromide related compds.

          (b) Desai, P. V.; Patny, A.; Gut, J.; Rosenthal, P. J.; Tekwani, B.; Srivastava, A.; Avery, M. Identification of novel parasitic cysteine protease inhibitors by use of virtual screening. 2. The available chemical directory. J. Med. Chem. 2006, 49, 1576– 1584,  DOI: 10.1021/jm0505765
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          50b
          Identification of Novel Parasitic Cysteine Protease Inhibitors by Use of Virtual Screening. 2. The Available Chemical Directory
          Desai, Prashant V.; Patny, Akshay; Gut, Jiri; Rosenthal, Philip J.; Tekwani, Babu; Srivastava, Anuradha; Avery, Mitchell
          Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2006), 49 (5), 1576-1584CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
          The incidence of parasitic infections such as malaria, leishmaniasis, and trypanosomiasis has been steadily increasing. Since the existing chemotherapy of these diseases suffers from lack of safe and effective drugs and/or the presence of widespread drug resistance, there is an urgent need for development of potent, mechanism-based antiparasitic agents against these diseases. Cysteine proteases have been established as valid targets for this purpose. The Available Chem. Directory consisting of nearly 355 000 compds. was screened in silico against the homol. models of plasmodial cysteine proteases, falcipain-2, and falcipain-3, to identify structurally diverse non-peptide inhibitors. The study led to identification of 22 inhibitors of parasitic cysteine proteases out of which 18 compds. were active against falcipain-2 and falcipain-3. Eight compds. exhibited dual activity against both enzymes. Addnl., four compds. were found to inhibit L. donovani cysteine protease. While one of the cysteine protease inhibitors also exhibited in vitro antiplasmodial activity with an IC50 value of 9.5 μM, others did not show noticeable antiplasmodial activity up to 20 μM. A model identifying important pharmacophoric features common to the structurally diverse falcipain-2 inhibitors has also been developed. Very few potent non-peptide inhibitors of the parasitic cysteine proteases have been reported so far, and identification of these novel and chem. diverse inhibitors should provide leads to be optimized into candidates to treat protozoal infections.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtlCnurw%253D&md5=a880a89b50d77b55b7b078522141faed
          open URL

          (c) Dar, A. A.; Enjamuri, N.; Shadab, M. D.; Ali, N.; Khan, A. T. Synthesis of unsymmetrical sulfides and their oxidation to sulfones to discover potent antileishmanial agents. ACS Comb. Sci. 2015, 17, 671– 681,  DOI: 10.1021/acscombsci.5b00044
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          50c
          Synthesis of Unsymmetrical Sulfides and Their Oxidation to Sulfones to Discover Potent Antileishmanial Agents
          Dar, Ajaz A.; Enjamuri, Nagasuresh; Shadab, Md.; Ali, Nahid; Khan, Abu T.
          ACS Combinatorial Science (2015), 17 (11), 671-681CODEN: ACSCCC; ISSN:2156-8944. (American Chemical Society)
          Unsym. sulfides were first synthesized using combinations of a 1,3-dicarbonyl, an arom. aldehyde, and a thiol in the presence of 10 mol % ethanolic piperidine. These sulfides derivs. were subsequently converted into corresponding sulfones via oxidn. in the presence of m-chloroperoxybenzoic acid (m-CPBA) at ice-bath to room temp. The former reaction was achieved at room temp. through one-pot three-component. The later was obtained in good yields using mild reaction conditions with flexibility in choice from a range of substrates. The antimicrobial properties of the newly synthesized sulfone derivs. were investigated against the protozoan parasite, Leishmania donovani, a causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis (VL). Nine sulfone derivs. were found to be efficacious and exhibited significant antimicrobial activity. Further, these compds. were nontoxic on murine peritoneal macrophages thus eliminating potential cytotoxicity in the host cells. These compds. may be indicated as potential leads in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis.

          (d) Sturino, C. F.; Neill, G. O.; Lachance, N.; Boyd, M.; Berthelette, C.; Labelle, M.; Li, L.; Roy, B.; Scheigetz, J.; Tsou, N.; Aubin, Y.; Bateman, K. P.; Chauret, N.; Day, S.           50d
          Discovery of a Potent and Selective Prostaglandin D2 Receptor Antagonist, [(3R)-4-(4-Chlorobenzyl)-7-fluoro-5-(methylsulfonyl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydrocyclopenta[b]indol-3-yl]-acetic Acid (MK-0524)
          Sturino, Claudio F.; O'Neill, Gary; Lachance, Nicolas; Boyd, Michael; Berthelette, Carl; Labelle, Marc; Li, Lianhai; Roy, Bruno; Scheigetz, John; Tsou, Nancy; Aubin, Yves; Bateman, Kevin P.; Chauret, Nathalie; Day, Stephen H.; Levesque, Jean-Francois; Seto, Carmai; Silva, Jose H.; Trimble, Laird A.; Carriere, Marie-Claude; Denis, Danielle; Greig, Gillian; Kargman, Stacia; Lamontagne, Sonia; Mathieu, Marie-Claude; Sawyer, Nicole; Slipetz, Deborah; Abraham, William M.; Jones, Tom; McAuliffe, Malia; Piechuta, Hana; Nicoll-Griffith, Deborah A.; Wang, Zhaoyin; Zamboni, Robert; Young, Robert N.; Metters, Kathleen M.
          Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2007), 50 (4), 794-806CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
          The discovery of the potent and selective prostaglandin D2 (PGD2) receptor (DP) antagonist [(3R)-4-(4-chlorobenzyl)-7-fluoro-5-(methylsulfonyl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydrocyclopenta[b]indol-3-yl]-acetic acid (13) is presented. Initial lead antagonists 6 and 7 were found to be potent and selective DP antagonists (DP Ki = 2.0 nM for each); however, they both suffered from poor pharmacokinetic profiles, short half-lives and high clearance rates in rats. Rat bile duct cannulation studies revealed that high concns. of parent drug were present in the biliary fluid (Cmax = 1100 μM for 6 and 3900 μM for 7). This pharmacokinetic liability was circumvented by replacing the 7-methylsulfone substituent present in 6 and 7 with a fluorine atom resulting in antagonists with diminished propensity for biliary excretion and with superior pharmacokinetic profiles. Further optimization led to the discovery of the potent and selective DP antagonist 13.
          >> More from SciFinder ®

          open URL

          Nickel-Catalyzed Synthesis of Diaryl Sulfones from Aryl Halides and Sodium Sulfinates
          Liu, Nai-Wei; Liang, Shuai; Margraf, Natalie; Shaaban, Saad; Luciano, Vanessa; Drost, Marcella; Manolikakes, Georg
          European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2018), 2018 (10), 1208-1210CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          A novel nickel-catalyzed cross-coupling of sulfinic acid salts with aryl halides is described. The reaction provides access to various diaryl sulfones in moderate to excellent yields. A broad range of functional groups and heteroarom. compds. is tolerated under the reaction conditions.

          A Convenient Synthesis of Sulfones via Light Promoted Coupling of Sodium Sulfinates and Aryl Halides
          Chen, Lei; Liang, Jie; Chen, Zhen-yu; Chen, Jie; Yan, Ming; Zhang, Xue-jing
          Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis (2019), 361 (5), 956-960CODEN: ASCAF7; ISSN:1615-4150. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          A convenient and efficient synthesis of sulfones RS(O)2R1 (R = Me, cyclopropyl, 4-methoxyphenyl, pyridin-3-yl, etc.; R1 = 4-cyanophenyl, pyridin-3-yl, pyrimidin-5-yl, etc.) from sulfinates RS(O)2Na and aryl halides R1X (X = Br, I, Cl) was developed. The reaction occurred under UV irradn. without transition metal catalyst or photocatalyst. A radical pathway via single-electron transfer (SET) of electron donor-acceptor (EDA) complex was proposed based on UV-vis spectroscopy, radical inhibiting and trapping expts.

          Cheng, Zhen; Sun, Pengchao; Tang, Ailing; Jin, Weiwei; Liu, Chenjiang

          A practical and switchable method for the synthesis of aryl sulfones and sulfoxides via sulfide oxidn. was developed. The chemoselectivities of products were simply controlled by reaction temp. using O2/air as the terminal oxidant and oxygen source. The broad substrate scope, easy realization of gram-scale prodn., and the simplification of a sulfide oxidn. system render the strategy attractive and valuable.

          Fe3O4/PEG-SO3H as a heterogeneous and magnetically-recyclable nanocatalyst for the oxidation of sulfides to sulfones or sulfoxides
          Mirfakhraei, Saeideh; Hekmati, Malak; Eshbala, Fereshteh Hosseini; Veisi, Hojat
          New Journal of Chemistry (2018), 42 (3), 1757-1761CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          A sulfonated-polyethylene glycol-coated Fe3O4 nanocomposite (Fe3O4/PEG-SO3H) as a greatly effective and ecol. nanocatalyst for the selective oxidn. of sulfides to sulfoxides or sulfones with high yields under solvent-free conditions by employing 30% hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant, is presented. A no. of sulfides contg. alc., ester, and aldehyde functional groups were effectively and selectively oxidized without altering the desired characteristics. The magnetic nanocatalyst (Fe3O4/PEG-SO3H) can be conveniently and swiftly retrieved through the utilization of an external magnetic tool and recycled for more than 10 reaction runs without significantly decreasing its catalytic behavior.

          Direct sulfonylation of anilines mediated by visible light
          Johnson, Tarn C.; Elbert, Bryony L.; Farley, Alistair J. M.; Gorman, Timothy W.; Genicot, Christophe; Lallemand, Benedicte; Pasau, Patrick; Flasz, Jakub; Castro, Jose L.; MacCoss, Malcolm; Dixon, Darren J.; Paton, Robert S.; Schofield, Christopher J.; Smith, Martin D.; Willis, Michael C.
          Chemical Science (2018), 9 (3), 629-633CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          Sulfones feature prominently in biol. active mols. and are key functional groups for org. synthesis. A mild, photoredox-catalyzed reaction for sulfonylation of aniline derivs. such as N,N-4-trimethylaniline, N,4-dimethylaniline and 4-methyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-1,4-benzoxazine with sulfinate salts RSO2Na (R = cyclopropyl, 4,4-difluorocyclohexyl, propan-2-yl, etc.) and demonstration of the utility of the method by the late-stage functionalization of drugs have been described. Key features of the method are the straightforward generation of sulfonyl radicals from bench-stable sulfinate salts and the use of simple aniline derivs. as convenient readily available coupling partners.

          C-H bond sulfonylation of anilines with the insertion of sulfur dioxide under metal-free conditions
          Zhou, Kaida; Zhang, Jun; Lai, Lifang; Cheng, Jiang; Sun, Jiangtao; Wu, Jie
          Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2018), 54 (54), 7459-7462CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          C-H bond sulfonylation of anilines with the insertion of sulfur dioxide under metal-free conditions was described. 2-Sulfonylanilines I [R = H, Me, F, Cl, MeO, Ts; R1 = NHMe, NHEt, NMe2; R2 = 4-BrC6H4SO2, 4-CO2EtC6H4SO2, 3,5-di-MeC6H3SO2, etc.] were generated in moderate to good yields through a three-component reaction of anilines, DABCO·(SO2)2 and aryldiazonium tetrafluoroborates under mild conditions. No metal catalysts or additives were needed for this transformation. This direct C-H functionalization was highly efficient and broad functional group tolerance was obsd. In the reaction process, the arylsulfonyl radical and the tertiary amine radical cation generated in situ from DABCO·(SO2)2 and aryldiazonium tetrafluoroborate were the key intermediates.

        53. 53
          (a) Cabrera-Afonso, M.; Lu, Z. P.; Kelly, C. B.; Lang, S. B.; Dykstra, R.; Gutierrez, O.; Molander, G. A. Engaging sulfinate salts via Ni/photoredox dual catalysis enables facile C sp2–SO 2 R coupling. Chem. Sci. 2018, 9, 3186– 3191,  DOI: 10.1039/C7SC05402E
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          53a
          Engaging sulfinate salts via Ni/photoredox dual catalysis enables facile Csp2-SO2R coupling
          Cabrera-Afonso, Maria Jesus; Lu, Zhi-Peng; Kelly, Christopher B.; Lang, Simon B.; Dykstra, Ryan; Gutierrez, Osvaldo; Molander, Gary A.
          Chemical Science (2018), 9 (12), 3186-3191CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          This report details the development and implementation of a strategy to construct aryl and heteroaryl sulfones via Ni/photoredox dual catalysis. Using aryl sulfinate salts, the C-S bond can be forged at room temp. under base-free conditions. A variety of aryl and heteroaryl halides is compatible with this approach. The broad tolerance and mild nature of the described reaction could potentially be employed to prep. sulfones with biol. relevance (e.g., in bioconjugation, drug substance synthesis, etc.) as demonstrated in the synthesis of drug-like compds. or their precursors. When paired with existing Ni/photoredox chem. for Csp3-Csp2 cross-coupling, an array of diverse sulfone scaffolds can be readily assembled from bifunctional electrophiles. A mechanistic manifold consistent with exptl. and computational data is presented.

          53b
          Organic photoredox catalysis enabled cross-coupling of arenediazonium and sulfinate salts: synthesis of (un)symmetrical diaryl/alkyl aryl sulfones
          Chawla, Ruchi; Yadav, Lal Dhar S.
          Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2019), 17 (19), 4761-4766CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          The first transition-metal- and external oxidant/reductant-free visible-light-mediated synthesis of (un)sym. diaryl/alkyl aryl sulfones from arenediazonium tetrafluoroborates and sodium sulfinates using eosin Y as an org. photoredox catalyst was reported. The utilization of visible light as an inexpensive and ecosustainable energy source, operational simplicity, ambient temp. and clean reaction in aq. acetonitrile were the salient features of the developed protocol. The desired sulfones were also synthesized via a one-pot, two-step process directly from anilines and sulfinate salts in good to excellent yields.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXnvVKhu78%253D&md5=4521a52ab7dfd0630f6cfb6303a30221
          open URL
          .
          (c) Zhu, D. L.; Wu, Q.; Li, H. Y.; Li, H. X.; Lang, J. P. Hantzsch ester as a visible-light photoredox catalyst for transition-metal-free coupling of arylhalides and arylsulfinates. Chem. – Eur. J. 2020, 26, 3484– 3488,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201905281
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          53c
          Hantzsch Ester as a Visible-Light Photoredox Catalyst for Transition-Metal-Free Coupling of Aryl halides and Arylsulfinates
          Zhu, Da-Liang; Wu, Qi; Li, Hai-Yan; Li, Hong-Xi; Lang, Jian-Ping
          Chemistry - A European Journal (2020), 26 (16), 3484-3488CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          Di-Et 2,6-dimethyl-1,4-dihydropyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate (HEH) was utilized as a visible-light photoredox catalyst for the cross coupling of aryl halides and aryl sulfinates without transition metal, sacrificial agent and mediator. This method was compatible with various functional groups and provided diaryl sulfones in good to high yields. Mechanistic studies indicated that this reaction underwent the stepwise light irradn. of HE-, single electron transfer (SET) in donor-acceptor complex (DAC) from *HE- to aryl halide, trapping of aryl radical with sulfinate and SET oxidn. of sulfone radical anion by HE. to sulfone by the DAC method.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXjvVKlt74%253D&md5=9bfba450601d9eb74808b6adc1934483
          open URL
          .
          (d) Liu, N. W.; Hofman, K.; Herbert, A.; Manolikakes, G. Visible-Light Photoredox/Nickel Dual Catalysis for the Cross-Coupling of Sulfinic Acid Salts with Aryl Iodides. Org. Lett. 2018, 20, 760– 763,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.orglett.7b03896
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          53d
          Visible-Light Photoredox/Nickel Dual Catalysis for the Cross-Coupling of Sulfinic Acid Salts with Aryl Iodides
          Liu, Nai-Wei; Hofman, Kamil; Herbert, Andre; Manolikakes, Georg
          Organic Letters (2018), 20 (3), 760-763CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
          In the presence of NiCl2, 2,2'-bipyridine, Ru(bpy)3Cl2, and tributylamine, aryl and heteroaryl iodides such as 4-iodoanisole underwent chemoselective coupling with sodium and lithium arylsulfinates and sodium methanesulfinate under blue LED irradn. at ambient temp. to yield diaryl and aryl Me sulfones such as 4-MeOC6H4SO2Ph. Lithium sulfinates were prepd. in situ via aryllithium reagents; pharmaceutical-derived aryl iodides were effective reactants for the coupling reaction.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXotFKntw%253D%253D&md5=5062a4f66d65019310c0c14fca60e00c

          Lawrence, S. A., Ed. Amines: Synthesis, Properties, and Applications; Cambridge University: Cambridge, 2006.

        55. 55
          Wang, L. M.; Kobayashi, K.; Arisawa, M.; Saito, S.; Naka, H. Pd/TiO2-photocatalyzed self-condensation of primary amines to afford secondary amines at ambient temperature. Org. Lett. 2019, 21, 341– 344,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.orglett.8b03271
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          55
          Pd/TiO2-Photocatalyzed Self-Condensation of Primary Amines To Afford Secondary Amines at Ambient Temperature
          Wang, Lyu-Ming; Kobayashi, Kensuke; Arisawa, Mitsuhiro; Saito, Susumu; Naka, Hiroshi
          Organic Letters (2019), 21 (2), 341-344CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
          Sym. secondary amines were synthesized by the self-condensation of primary amines over a palladium-loaded titanium dioxide (Pd/TiO2) photocatalyst. The reactions afforded a series of secondary amines in moderate to excellent isolated yields at ambient temp. (30 °C, in cyclopentyl Me ether). Applicability for one-pot pharmaceutical synthesis was demonstrated by a photocatalytic reaction sequence of self-condensation of an amine followed by N-alkylation of the resulting secondary amine with an alc.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXit1CnsL7L&md5=32b83a7a5a6879cd27cd6c33134d725c
