        56. 56
          (a) Nishimura, T.; Takiguchi, Y.; Hayashi, T. Effect of chiral diene ligands in rhodium-catalyzed asymmetric addition of arylboronic acids to α,β-unsaturated sulfonyl compounds. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 9086– 9089,  DOI: 10.1021/ja303109q
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          56a
          Effect of Chiral Diene Ligands in Rhodium-Catalyzed Asymmetric Addition of Arylboronic Acids to α,β-Unsaturated Sulfonyl Compounds
          Nishimura, Takahiro; Takiguchi, Yuka; Hayashi, Tamio
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (22), 9086-9089CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Asym. addn. of arylboronic acids to α,β-unsatd. sulfonyl compds. proceeded in the presence of a rhodium catalyst coordinated with a chiral diene ligand to give high yields of the addn. products with high enantioselectivity (96->99.5% ee). The diene ligand was proved to be essential for the formation of the addn. products, while the use of a bisphosphine ligand mainly gave the cine-substitution product.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XnsVertbs%253D&md5=d0429db8311a23209922f6b1d3c89ce7

          (b) Pandey, G.; Tiwari, K. N.; Puranik, V. G. Use of enantiomerically pure 7-azabicyclo [2.2. 1] heptan-2-ol as a chiral template for the synthesis of aminocyclitols. Org. Lett. 2008, 10, 3611– 3614,  DOI: 10.1021/ol801381t
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          56b
          Use of Enantiomerically Pure 7-Azabicyclo[2.2.1]heptan-2-ol as a Chiral Template for the Synthesis of Aminocyclitols
          Pandey, Ganesh; Tiwari, Keshri Nath; Puranik, V. G.
          Organic Letters (2008), 10 (16), 3611-3614CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
          Using enantiopure 7-azabicyclo[2.2.1]heptane-2-ol, the synthesis of cis- as well as trans-2-aminocyclohexanols, dihydroconduramine E-1, and ent-conduramine F-1 has been described.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXovVWjtL8%253D&md5=f42dca718afc0eeee1715db278460860

          .
          (c) Ravelli, D.; Montanaro, S.; Zema, M.; Fagnoni, M.; Albini, A. A Tin-free, radical photocatalyzed addition to vinyl sulfones. Adv. Synth. Catal. 2011, 353, 3295– 3300,  DOI: 10.1002/adsc.201100591
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          56c
          A Tin-Free, Radical Photocatalyzed Addition to Vinyl Sulfones
          Ravelli, Davide; Montanaro, Sara; Zema, Michele; Fagnoni, Maurizio; Albini, Angelo
          Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis (2011), 353 (18), 3295-3300CODEN: ASCAF7; ISSN:1615-4150. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          Radical conjugate addn. onto vinyl sulfones was achieved by means of a convenient, tin-free procedure. This was based on the photocatalyzed C-H bond activation in aldehydes, amides, ethers and even cycloalkanes by using tetrabutylammonium decatungstate (TBADT). The reaction was likewise effective for the functionalization of β-substituted vinyl sulfones. The products are useful building blocks and were obtained in satisfactory yields both under artificial UV light and under sunlight, so demonstrating the "green" potential of the process.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsFykurrJ&md5=c0087f38422722f14a84dbfb962a2950
          open URL
          .
          (d) Noshi, M. N.; Elawa, A.; Torres, E.; Fuchs, P. L. Conversion of cyclic vinyl sulfones to transposed vinyl phosphonates. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007, 129, 11242– 11247,  DOI: 10.1021/ja072890p
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          56d
          Conversion of Cyclic Vinyl Sulfones to Transposed Vinyl Phosphonates
          Noshi, Mohammad N.; El-Awa, Ahmad; Torres, Eduardo; Fuchs, Philip L.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (36), 11242-11247CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Functionalized cyclic vinyl sulfones were directly converted to the "polarity reversed" vinyl phosphonates through an efficient one pot procedure. Ozonolysis of these vinyl sulfones and vinyl phosphonates furnish complementary sets of termini-differentiated ester-aldehydes. This strategy has been applied for prepn. of segments needed for the synthesis of Aplyronine A. The scope and limitations of this transformation were defined.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXptVejs70%253D&md5=418e699fb3173b37eb7150017b5ab571

        57. 57
          Frankel, B. A.; Bentley, M.; Kruger, R. G.; McCafferty, D. G. Vinyl sulfones: inhibitors of SrtA, a transpeptidase required for cell wall protein anchoring and virulence in Staphylococcus aureus. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126, 3404– 3405,  DOI: 10.1021/ja0390294
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          57
          Vinyl sulfones: inhibitors of SrtA, a transpeptidase required for cell wall protein anchoring and virulence in Staphylococcus aureus
          Frankel, Brenda A.; Bentley, Matthew; Kruger, Ryan G.; McCafferty, Dewey G.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (11), 3404-3405CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Several small mol. vinyl sulfones exhibited irreversible time-dependent inhibition of the S. aureus sortase SrtA in vitro. A representative of these compds. was shown to impair the ability of S. aureus bacteria to bind fibronectin-coated surfaces through in vivo inhibition of SrtA-mediated linkage of fibronectin to the cell surface. These data highlight the potential use of small mol. vinyl sulfones as chemotherapeutics to prevent adhesion to and colonization of host tissues during S. aureus infection.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhsFyitro%253D&md5=79012f5d1bb8b58dbbdba6dbc9cee799

        58. 58
          Kudryavtsev, K. V.; Bentley, M. L.; McCafferty, D. G. Probing of the cis-5-phenyl proline scaffold as a platform for the synthesis of mechanism-based inhibitors of the Staphylococcus aureus sortase SrtA isoform. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2009, 17, 2886– 2893,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmc.2009.02.008
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          58
          Probing of the cis-5-phenyl proline scaffold as a platform for the synthesis of mechanism-based inhibitors of the Staphylococcus aureus sortase SrtA isoform
          Kudryavtsev, Konstantin V.; Bentley, Matthew L.; McCafferty, Dewey G.
          Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2009), 17 (7), 2886-2893CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier B.V.)
          Cis-5-Ph prolinates with electrophilic substituents at the fourth position of a pyrrolidine ring were synthesized by 1,3-dipolar cycloaddn. of arylimino esters with divinyl sulfone and acrylonitrile. 4-Vinylsulfonyl 5-Ph prolinates inhibit Staphylococcus aureus sortase SrtA irreversibly by modification of the enzyme Cys184 and could be used as hits for the development of antibacterials and antivirulence agents.

        59. 59
          (a) Reddick, J. J.; Cheng, J. M.; Roush, W. R. Relative rates of Michael reactions of 2′-(Phenethyl)thiol with vinyl sulfones, vinyl sulfonate esters, and vinyl sulfonamides relevant to vinyl sulfonyl cysteine protease inhibitors. Org. Lett. 2003, 5, 1967– 1970,  DOI: 10.1021/ol034555l
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          59a
          Relative rates of Michael reactions of 2'-(Phenethyl)thiol with vinyl sulfones, vinyl sulfonate esters, and vinyl sulfonamides relevant to vinyl sulfonyl cysteine protease inhibitors
          Reddick, Jason J.; Cheng, Jianming; Roush, William R.
          Organic Letters (2003), 5 (11), 1967-1970CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
          The relative rates of Michael addns. of 2'-(phenethyl)thiol to representative vinyl sulfonyl Michael acceptors were measured. The dependence of the reactivity of the Michael acceptor on the nature of the sulfonyl substituent was detd. in order to evaluate the effect of these substituents on the inactivation kinetics of comparably substituted vinyl sulfonyl cysteine protease inhibitors. The rates of these Michael addns. vary over 3 orders of magnitude, with Ph vinyl sulfonate esters being ca. 3000-fold more reactive than N-benzyl vinyl sulfonamides.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXjtlWgsL8%253D&md5=45db6f5a691a8313ac20c0359c1f988c

          .
          (b) Roush, W. R.; Gwaltney, S. L.; Cheng, J.; Scheidt, K. A.; Mckerrow, J. H.; Hansell, E. Vinyl sulfonate esters and vinyl sulfonamides: potent, irreversible inhibitors of cysteine proteases. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1998, 120, 10994– 10995,  DOI: 10.1021/ja981792o
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          59b
          Vinyl Sulfonate Esters and Vinyl Sulfonamides: Potent, Irreversible Inhibitors of Cysteine Proteases
          Roush, William R.; Gwaltney, Stephen L., II; Cheng, Jianming; Scheidt, Karl A.; McKerrow, James H.; Hansell, Elizabeth
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (1998), 120 (42), 10994-10995CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          A series of vinyl sulfonate esters, vinyl sulfonamides, and vinyl sulfones I (R = OEt, OPh, NHMe, NHCH2Ph, NHCH2CH2Ph, NHPh, Ph, CH2Ph, CH2CH2Ph; R1 = CH2CH2Ph, Me) was prepd. as an effort to develop potent and selective cruzain inhibitors. Alkyl vinyl sulfonamides, e.g. I (R = NHCH2Ph, R1 = Me), were relatively weak inhibitors of cruzain, while aryl vinyl sulfonamides and sulfonate esters, e.g. I (R = OEt, OPh, NHPh; R1 = Me, CH2CH2Ph) were much more potent.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXmsVKqurw%253D&md5=0c1be71c361d58f51704de2d2b4ede7b
          open URL
        60. 60
          (a) Yoon, T. P.; Ischay, M. A.; Du, J. Visible light photocatalysis as a greener approach to photochemical synthesis. Nat. Chem. 2010, 2, 527– 532,  DOI: 10.1038/nchem.687
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          60a
          Visible light photocatalysis as a greener approach to photochemical synthesis
          Yoon, Tehshik P.; Ischay, Michael A.; Du, Juana
          Nature Chemistry (2010), 2 (7), 527-532CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
          A review. Light can be considered an ideal reagent for environmentally friendly, 'green' chem. synthesis; unlike many conventional reagents, light is non-toxic, generates no waste, and can be obtained from renewable sources. Nevertheless, the need for high-energy UV radiation in most org. photochem. processes has limited both the practicality and environmental benefits of photochem. synthesis on industrially relevant scales. This Perspective describes recent approaches to the use of metal polypyridyl photocatalysts in synthetic org. transformations. Given the remarkable photophys. properties of these complexes, these new transformations, which use Ru(bpy)32+ and related photocatalysts, can be conducted using almost any source of visible light, including both store-bought fluorescent light bulbs and ambient sunlight. Transition metal photocatalysis thus represents a promising strategy towards the development of practical, scalable industrial processes with great environmental benefits.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXnvVSiur0%253D&md5=fbad76c04a5888d7d595441ea70c2e10
          open URL
          .
          (b) Meadows, D. C.; Gervay-Hague, J. Vinyl sulfones: Synthetic preparations and medicinal chemistry applications. Med. Res. Rev. 2006, 26, 793– 814,  DOI: 10.1002/med.20074
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          60b
          Vinyl sulfones: synthetic preparations and medicinal chemistry applications
          Meadows, D. Christopher; Gervay-Hague, Jacquelyn
          Medicinal Research Reviews (2006), 26 (6), 793-814CODEN: MRREDD; ISSN:0198-6325. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
          A review. Vinyl sulfones have long been known for their synthetic utility in org. chem., easily participating in 1,4-addn. reactions and cycloaddn. reactions. This functional group has also recently been shown to potently inhibit a variety of enzymic processes providing unique properties for drug design and medicinal chem. This review includes traditional methods used for the synthesis of vinyl sulfones, but focuses mainly on newer reactions applied to vinyl sulfones, including olefin metathesis, conjugate redn., asym. dihydroxylation (AD), and the use of vinyl sulfones to arrive at highly functionalized targets, all illustrating the rich and versatile chem. this group can efficiently perform. Germinal disulfones are discussed with respect to their formation, reactions, and medicinal applications of this underused functional group.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xht12qsrbN&md5=5a8b7fe52749040e758fa9ac9132cab3
          open URL
          .
          (c) Mulina, O. M.; Ilovaisky, A. I.; Parshin, V. D.; Terent’ev, A. O. Oxidative Sulfonylation of Multiple Carbon-Carbon bonds with Sulfonyl Hydrazides, Sulfinic Acids and their Salts. Adv. Synth. Catal. 2020, 362, 4579– 4654,  DOI: 10.1002/adsc.202000708
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          60c
          Oxidative Sulfonylation of Multiple Carbon-Carbon bonds with Sulfonyl Hydrazides, Sulfinic Acids and their Salts
          Mulina, Olga M.; Ilovaisky, Alexey I.; Parshin, Vadim D.; Terent'ev, Alexander O.
          Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis (2020), 362 (21), 4579-4654CODEN: ASCAF7; ISSN:1615-4150. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          A review. Methods for oxidative sulfonylation of multiple bonds involving sulfonyl hydrazides, sulfinic acids and their salts as sulfonylation reagents was focussed. Under oxidative conditions, they generate sulfonyl radicals, trapped by multiple carbon-carbon bonds resulting in a variety of SO2-contg. products: mainly, vinyl and alkynyl sulfones, hydroxy-, keto, and halo-substituted sulfones, sulfonylated derivs. of carbo- and heterocycles. This exhaustive review summarized 321 refs. from 1996 to 2020 with the specialization of the studies of the last five years, and is divided into the chapters according to the classes of compds. being sulfonylated.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXhs1Klu7rJ&md5=8d1832d583a81de3b75f2ae16a16014d
          open URL
        61. 61
          Ischay, M. A.; Anzovino, M. E.; Du, J.; Yoon, T. P. Efficient visible light photocatalysis of [2+2] enone cycloadditions. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 12886– 12887,  DOI: 10.1021/ja805387f
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          61
          Efficient Visible Light Photocatalysis of [2+2] Enone Cycloadditions
          Ischay, Michael A.; Anzovino, Mary E.; Du, Juana; Yoon, Tehshik P.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (39), 12886-12887CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          The authors report that Ru(bpy)3Cl2 can serve as a visible light photocatalyst for [2+2] enone cycloaddns (bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine). A variety of aryl enones participate readily in the reaction, and the diastereoselectivity in the formation of the cyclobutane products is excellent. The authors propose a mechanism in which a photogenerated Ru(bpy)3+ complex promotes one-electron redn. of the enone substrate, which undergoes subsequent radical anion cycloaddn. The efficiency of this process is extremely high, which allows rapid, high-yielding [2+2] cyclizations to be conducted using incident sunlight as the only source of irradn.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtVymtLvL&md5=608e5fd4b3ef464d6216d633f2ae5f84
          open URL
